review_title: Great place to work; friendly people, decent leadership.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Wichita Falls, TX
pros: Texans are always welcoming and friendly. This was true at the hospital as well as the surrounding area. The work environment at the hospital was positive and I felt that the management was good which is not always easy to find in healthcare anywhere. I was a traveler there, so they were happy to see me and have the extra help. But aside from that, I think the staff was generally satisfied with their jobs and it showed.
cons: Wichita Falls isn't the most exciting place, but the surrounding prairie is really pretty and dramatic. As far as the hospital itself, I think the only thing I found negative were a couple of the individuals in the department I was in. Those types are everywhere though, not just at this  hospital: you know them, they are the ones who disappear when a patient needs a suppository or a new IV. There were no more of these types at United than at other places I have worked.

job_title: Coordination of Benefits in Beacon Falls, CT
pros: Meeting new people. Relationships I made with the customers. Being part of the Motor Vehicle and Workers Compensation division. I was personally selected to work that and I truly enjoyed that.
cons: Managers sitting on top of you. Some co-workers extremely loud on the phones that were working in different areas like Medicare or basic Insurance information. No Personal time so many people came in to work very sick and working in a small area everyone got sick. Mandatory 10 plus hour days. Most of the time did not mind but in some cases it was very difficult we all had families so we as a team would try to work something out to get thru it.

job_title: Advanced Practice Nurse in Greensboro, NC
pros: Excellent benefits, home base/remote, holidays and weekends off,
cons: All calls unethically  monitored for ideas, strategies, weapons, training, and no credit provided for calls used.    Managers were not credentialed with master degrees, or BS degrees.  Therefore, unable to recognize  employee needs for continuous improvement, trends for growth, and creditable training.  Friends promoted into leads rolls.  Management team had obvious on the job love affairs.  Productive employees expected to lose a lunch hour to catch up team/individuals work, while they took a lunch hour/break.  No one monitored leadership.  Leadership would reprimand staff for speaking with senior management when visiting the campus.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Wichita Falls, TX
pros: Raises every year based on performance, good benefits including dental, eye, family leave, short term disability, long term disability, orthodontics, etc.., above average pay, in house gym, discounts on some cell phone plans, yearly bonuses in May if requirements are met, night/weekend shift differential, tution assistance, particularly for medical students, incentive pay for referring an RN that gets hired, the CEO is always working on improving hospital proceedures, they strive for competitive benefits/pay  in house cafeteria open during select overnight hours as well & nice gift options for employment anniversaries such as 5 year.
cons: Only pay up to 6 years of severance pay & only if you don't find a job w/in 3 months of getting laid off.  Review process for management doesn't specify which manager you are rating.

job_title: Anonymous in Wichita Falls, TX
pros: You get to know the physicians here very well and has a nice community feel. A wide variety of patient demographic is served since this hospitals pulls from several counties.  A beautiful new surgery tower has been built in recent years.
cons: There is a lack of local competition for wages and standards of care. This hospital is very expensive. It takes a long time to work your way up the food chain as experienced staff are tenacious about their positions and have little incentive to share.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Wichita Falls, TX
pros: United Regional is a non-profit hospital so the profit goes back in to the hospital and not in a shareholding board-member's pocket. Because of this, United Regional has money to invest in expansion, renovation, and hiring and retaining quality workers. The mission statement (divided into two statements) is: PASSION- to provide excellence in healthcare to the communities we serve. PURPOSE-to make a positive difference in the lives of others. These are more than catchy slogans designed to impress the public. The CEO and Management of the hospital actively work toward these goals and over the last 15 years or so, have made some impressive changes by implementing nationally recognized systems specifically designed to bring patient care to the highest standards possible. They actively engage employees by having them set goals within their own department to reach these standards and provide bonuses yearly based on achievement of those goals. The bonuses go to the employees, not the management. United Regional also provides feedback in "Employee Forums" four times a year  where the CEO speaks to every employee about a wide range of hospital issues from "State of the Union" to tracking bonus status to gossip. They also put out a monthly magazine and weekly email "What's going on" letters in addition to having an active employee website that provides information, free education opportunities and tuition reimbursement information. There are celebration events at Christmas, during Hospital Week, during Nurses Week as well as an annual All Employee Event where the entire staff of the hospital gets bused offsite to see a play (usually involving senior management dress in hilarious outfits and a really good speaker). The hospital also regularly compares employee earnings to hospitals of similar size and makeup to ensure that they are competitive with wages and retain employees. They give across the board pay increases if they find they are falling behind in an area. The benefits are good and the health insurance has remained remarkably stable despite nationwide increases in cost to the employee in most companies. United Regional is a hospital that takes it's responsibility to patients and employees very seriously and works hard to be the best it can be. If you are willing to do the same, there is a good job in there for you somewhere.
cons: It is in Wichita Falls, Texas which is located in the vast purgatory between Dallas / Fort Worth and Oklahoma City. It is usually way to hot, sometimes way too cold and for two weeks in spring and two weeks in summer it is perfect weather. The hospital takes a while to learn to navigate. It is two buildings (the new one is called a "Tower"- I don't know why) connected by a "Sky Bridge " that connects them over a street below. No two floors in either building have the same floor pattern. Not all the elevators reach all the floors and the "Tower" elevators talk to you in that creepy computer voice that manages to say "Going up" in a disjointed way that sounds like it was spliced together from two different speeches given by someone who is not quite right to start with.

review_title: Organization is good but the department management is hell
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Wichita Falls, TX
pros: the organization itself is okay. people are friendly.
cons: there is no communication between departments. everything is done according to "what would please the eyes." Department specific--management takes everything personal, punishes you for having alternate opinion, cannot cope with change and still manage like they did 50 years ago. They are rude and condescending. They put themselves first over everything, and have no sense of team. Awful at communicating, closed off, and very arrogant, Possibly a little sexist, and racist.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Wichita Falls, TX

Low morale in lots of departments.
